essays.title: Divine Dividends: How Chinese Religious Traditions Shape Corporate Generosity

questions.question: What central argument does the essay make about Chinese corporate behaviour?

options.text: Corporate decisions are shaped only by regulations and profit motives.
Religious and cultural traditions influence financial practices such as dividend payments.
Chinese firms rarely pay dividends regardless of circumstances.
Only Western values shape modern capitalism.

questions.question: Which religious tradition had the stronger influence on dividend generosity according to the study?

options.text: Taoism, because it values balance.
Buddhism, because it emphasizes giving and karma.
Confucianism, because it values hierarchy.
Christianity, because of the Protestant ethic.

questions.question: Why were state-owned enterprises less influenced by local religious values?

options.text: They are primarily guided by international investors.
Their dividend policies are tied to government goals, limiting cultural influence.
They lack exposure to nearby temples.
They are forbidden from paying dividends.

questions.question: How did religion serve as an informal governance mechanism in Chinese firms?

options.text: By replacing all formal legal frameworks.
By discouraging exploitation and promoting fairness, even where legal enforcement was weak.
By mandating dividend payments through temple rules.
By reducing the role of shareholders altogether.

questions.question: What is meant by the essay’s statement that ‘culture is the software and policy is the hardware’?

options.text: Policies determine dividend size, while culture controls profitability.
Both cultural norms and formal regulations must align for smooth corporate governance.
Culture completely overrides policy in shaping firms.
Policies are temporary, while culture is irrelevant.

questions.question: Which of the following best captures the broader implication of the essay?

options.text: Capitalism everywhere functions independently of cultural and ethical traditions.
Religious and cultural traditions can make capitalism more ethical and sustainable.
Only Asian capitalism is influenced by religion.
Dividend payments are irrelevant to corporate ethics.

essays.title: Joseph Wright of Derby: Painting the Age of Enlightenment

questions.question: What central theme connects Joseph Wright’s famous works such as the Orrery and the Air Pump?

options.text: The dominance of religious symbolism in art.
The integration of science and Enlightenment ideas into painting.
The glorification of political leaders.
The focus on natural landscapes only.

questions.question: Which artistic technique did Wright famously use to dramatize scientific demonstrations?

options.text: Fresco painting.
Chiaroscuro, inspired by Caravaggio’s use of candlelight.
Cubism with geometric abstraction.
Watercolour washes for light effects.

questions.question: Why was Joseph Wright never fully accepted into the Royal Academy?

options.text: His subject matter did not fit into traditional categories like history or religion.
He only painted landscapes and portraits.
He worked exclusively in Rome.
He lacked technical painting skills.

questions.question: How did Wright’s works reflect the philosophical idea of the Sublime?

options.text: By showing the insignificance of mankind against vast cosmic forces.
By celebrating the authority of the monarchy.
By focusing only on decorative beauty.
By rejecting all scientific themes.

questions.question: What role did Derby and the Lunar Society play in Wright’s career?

options.text: They connected him with leading scientists and industrialists who inspired his art.
They provided him with commissions for royal portraits.
They trained him in fresco painting.
They discouraged him from painting science.

questions.question: What is the significance of Wright’s Orrery painting today?

options.text: It symbolizes how art captured Enlightenment science and is now a centrepiece of Derby Museum.
It demonstrates the decline of scientific thought in Britain.
It is considered Wright’s only landscape work.
It was rejected and destroyed by the Royal Academy.

essays.title: Hidden Fire: El Chichón and the Global Risks of Volcanoes

questions.question: Why was the eruption of El Chichón in 1982 particularly surprising?

options.text: It erupted sideways, similar to Mount St Helens.
It had been quiet for centuries, with little to no prior monitoring or warning signs.
It was the largest eruption ever recorded.
It occurred in a densely monitored and well-prepared region.

questions.question: What global consequence followed the El Chichón eruption?

options.text: It permanently increased Earth’s temperature.
It caused volcanic particles to settle only within Mexico.
It triggered atmospheric cooling and contributed to a devastating drought in East Africa.
It initiated a new ice age across both hemispheres.

questions.question: Why are many dangerous volcanoes overlooked in global monitoring efforts?

options.text: They erupt too frequently to be studied effectively.
Scientific and media attention tends to focus on famous volcanoes with frequent eruptions.
They are only located in uninhabited regions.
They are mostly underwater and impossible to measure.

questions.question: What makes forecasting volcanic eruptions so difficult, even with instruments?

options.text: Most warning signs always lead to eruptions.
Many unrest signals never culminate in eruptions, and volcanoes can erupt with very short warning times.
Technology cannot detect earthquakes or gas emissions.
Volcanoes in populated areas behave completely predictably.

questions.question: What broader lesson does El Chichón teach about volcanic risk?

options.text: Only active, frequently erupting volcanoes pose real danger.
Even quiet, seemingly dormant volcanoes can cause catastrophic global impacts.
Volcanoes are no longer capable of influencing global climate.
Eruptions only matter for local communities, not the wider world.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the newly founded Global Volcano Risk Alliance?

options.text: To promote tourism around famous volcanoes.
To advocate for monitoring, preparedness, and international cooperation on overlooked volcanic threats.
To fund movies about volcanic disasters.
To permanently prevent volcanic eruptions through technology.

essays.title: Katie Brandt: From Personal Tragedy to Caregiver Advocacy

questions.question: What early signs of Mike’s illness did Katie notice before his diagnosis?

options.text: He had severe memory loss.
He became indifferent, compulsive, and showed personality changes.
He began experiencing hallucinations.
He lost the ability to walk.

questions.question: Why was Mike’s illness initially misdiagnosed?

options.text: Frontotemporal dementia symptoms mimic depression and stress.
The disease progresses too quickly to detect.
Katie did not seek medical help until very late.
MRI scans always confirm frontotemporal dementia.

questions.question: How is frontotemporal dementia different from Alzheimer’s in its early stages?

options.text: FTD primarily affects memory, while Alzheimer’s changes personality first.
FTD preserves memory initially but alters personality and judgment.
FTD and Alzheimer’s show identical symptoms.
FTD only affects the elderly, while Alzheimer’s affects the young.

questions.question: What turning point pushed Katie into advocacy work?

options.text: Mike’s sudden recovery inspired her to help others.
Her grief after Mike’s death led her to volunteer and later become an advocate.
She received government funding for a new project.
Her father encouraged her to pursue caregiving.

questions.question: What policy change in 2020 was significant for caregivers like Katie?

options.text: Expansion of Medicare to all caregivers regardless of income.
The Older Americans Act allowed dementia patients under 60 to access support programs.
The Affordable Care Act created free dementia clinics nationwide.
All caregivers were given direct financial stipends by the government.

questions.question: What broader lesson does Katie’s story highlight about caregiving?

options.text: Caregiving is primarily a medical challenge.
Caregiving is as much about systemic support and recognition as medical treatment.
Caregiving always leads to financial stability for families.
Caregiving problems are already fully addressed by current systems.

essays.title: The Big Bang Theory: Origins, Evidence, and Challenges

questions.question: What observation by Edwin Hubble and Milton Humason supported the idea of an expanding universe?

options.text: Stars in the Milky Way were moving closer together.
Galaxies were moving away at speeds proportional to their distances.
The Sun’s orbit around the galaxy was slowing down.
Dark matter halos were discovered.

questions.question: Why was anisotropy (tiny irregularities in matter distribution) essential in the early universe?

options.text: It allowed gravity to create stars and galaxies.
It stopped the universe from collapsing.
It explained the presence of dark energy.
It prevented cosmic inflation.

questions.question: What discovery by Penzias and Wilson in 1964 provided strong evidence for the Big Bang?

options.text: The first spiral galaxy rotation curves.
The cosmic microwave background radiation.
Dark matter halos around galaxies.
The accelerating expansion of the universe.

questions.question: What is the role of dark matter in galaxy formation?

options.text: It slows down cosmic expansion.
It provides the gravitational framework for galaxies to form and rotate correctly.
It emits radiation detected as the CMB.
It prevents anisotropies from forming.

questions.question: What unexpected discovery in the late 1990s led to the revival of Einstein’s cosmological constant?

options.text: The universe’s expansion was accelerating, not slowing down.
The universe was shrinking in size.
Dark matter could explain all missing mass.
The CMB temperature was higher than predicted.

questions.question: What current challenge is referred to as the 'Hubble tension'?

options.text: Disagreement between early and late universe measurements of the Hubble constant.
The inability to detect dark matter directly.
The discovery of gravitational waves contradicting inflation.
Supernovae no longer acting as reliable standard candles.

essays.title: Quantum Mechanics, Consciousness, and the Forgotten Phenomenology

questions.question: What central issue does the 'measurement problem' in quantum mechanics address?

options.text: Why quantum mechanics cannot explain atomic structure.
How a quantum superposition becomes a definite outcome upon measurement.
Why electrons have spin in two forms.
How lasers and superconductors function.

questions.question: According to von Neumann, what collapses a quantum superposition into a definite state?

options.text: Random physical noise in the apparatus.
The observer’s consciousness.
The laws of classical mechanics.
External cosmic forces beyond physics.

questions.question: What concern did Hilary Putnam raise about von Neumann’s argument?

options.text: It made quantum mechanics too mathematical to apply in practice.
If consciousness is needed, quantum theory cannot be applied to the entire Universe.
It ignored the role of detectors in experiments.
It conflicted with relativity theory.

questions.question: How did London and Bauer’s 1939 pamphlet reinterpret the measurement process?

options.text: They argued that measurement outcomes are determined by hidden variables.
They adopted a phenomenological view, where consciousness and the world are correlated.
They denied that superpositions exist at all.
They claimed the act of measurement has no philosophical implications.

questions.question: What role does the ‘faculty of introspection’ play in London and Bauer’s account?

options.text: It mathematically calculates wave functions.
It allows the observer to reflect, separate from the superposition, and ‘make objective’ a definite outcome.
It ensures the measurement apparatus behaves classically.
It removes consciousness from the measurement process.

questions.question: Which broader implication does the phenomenological approach to quantum mechanics suggest?

options.text: Quantum mechanics should be treated only as a mathematical tool, not a theory of knowledge.
Quantum mechanics embodies our correlative participation with the world, making it a theory of knowledge as well.
Philosophy has no role in understanding physics.
Measurement problems are solved only by technology, not philosophy.
